Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Korea
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Tyler Fleetham of Arizona State University to conduct a research project, entitled "Temperature and light intensity dependence of organic solar cells," during the summer of 2012 at Seoul National University in Seoul, South Korea. The host scientist is Professor Changhee Lee.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is a comprehensive understanding of factors that affect the photocurrent and diode behavior of organic solar cells under various operating conditions. Through characterizing photovoltaic parameters including the open circuit voltage and photocurrent at various temperatures for a wide range of materials the research results promise a greater understanding of the photovoltaic mechanisms of organic solar cells at a molecular level and lead to understanding the effect of molecular design on solar cell performance.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background: Organic solar cells employing cheap, easily synthesized small molecular materials have been long touted as a viable next generation energy source due to the potential advantages of cheap, high throughput production as well as their imagined application in a large number of form factors including transparent, energy-producing window tinting, roofing shingles, or even integration into wearable devices. However, compared to the traditional silicon-based solar cells that currently dominate the market, organic photovoltaics have typically exhibited much lower efficiencies. The purpose of this research project was to explore the influence of molecular design, environmental conditions, and device structure on device performance parameters which could lead to higher efficiencies in organic photovoltaic cells. In particular, there is significant inquiry into the factors affecting the open circuit voltage(the voltage at which the net device current is zero) which remains much lower than the theoretical maximum voltages of these devices thus reducing the efficiency of these devices. Since the open circuit voltage is simply the condition in which the diode current equals the photocurrent, the measurement of both the diode (dark) current and the photocurrent independently is extremely important. In particular, the research seeks to uncover why some materials demonstrate high open circuit voltages at room temperature while others only demonstrate maximum values at temperatures as low as 100-150K. Thus understating the effect of molecular properties as well as temperature and on the open circuit voltage is important to further the understanding of molecular design principles for more efficient organic photovoltaic devices.

Experimental Results: At Seoul National University the PI designed and built an experimental setup for direct measurement of the photocurrent as a function of voltage. This setup provided complimentary information to the dark current data which is normally measured in solar cells thus expanding the ability to analyze what factors affect the current voltage behavior of OPV devices. By measuring the photocurrent versus voltage it can be determined if the low open circuit voltage is a result of a high diode current (dark current measurement) or the result of a drop off in photocurrent at higher voltages: i.e. is the open circuit voltage photocurrent or diode current limited. Furthermore, a liquid helium cryostat was integrated with the photocurrent set up to vary the temperature of the device. The photocurrent and dark currents as a function of voltage were measured at various low temperatures in order to provide insight into the factors that affect the open circuit voltage. Furthermore, the materials used in the devices were varied in order to determine the effect of molecular properties on the open circuit values as well as the influence of molecular design on the temperature at which maximum attainable open circuit voltage can be achieved. Preliminary results indicate that in some material systems which have a very low diode current, the open circuit voltage is limited by a drop off in photocurrent at a voltage near the open circuit condition. This behavior ultimately yields minimal change in open circuit voltage as the dark current is lowered with decreasing temperature giving nearly maximum obtainable voltage at room temperature. Yet in another material system, the photocurrent dropped off at voltages much beyond the open circuit condition but the dark current was high enough to limit the open circuit voltage. Thus, as the dark current is lowered with decreasing temperature the open circuit voltage was affected yielding maximum obtainable voltages at low temperatures. These results have currently yielded one publication yet uncovering more information on what effect the properties of the organic ...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Background: Organic solar cells employing cheap, easily synthesized small molecular materials have been long touted as a viable next generation energy source due to the potential advantages of cheap, high throughput production as well as their imagined application in a large number of form factors including transparent, energy-producing window tinting, roofing shingles, or even integration into wearable devices. However, compared to the traditional silicon-based solar cells that currently dominate the market, organic photovoltaics have typically exhibited much lower efficiencies. The purpose of this research project was to explore the influence of molecular design, environmental conditions, and device structure on device performance parameters which could lead to higher efficiencies in organic photovoltaic cells. In particular, there is significant inquiry into the factors affecting the open circuit voltage(the voltage at which the net device current is zero) which remains much lower than the theoretical maximum voltages of these devices thus reducing the efficiency of these devices. Since the open circuit voltage is simply the condition in which the diode current equals the photocurrent, the measurement of both the diode (dark) current and the photocurrent independently is extremely important. In particular, the research seeks to uncover why some materials demonstrate high open circuit voltages at room temperature while others only demonstrate maximum values at temperatures as low as 100-150K. Thus understating the effect of molecular properties as well as temperature and on the open circuit voltage is important to further the understanding of molecular design principles for more efficient organic photovoltaic devices. Experimental Results: At Seoul National University the PI designed and built an experimental setup for direct measurement of the photocurrent as a function of voltage. This setup provided complimentary information to the dark current data which is normally measured in solar cells thus expanding the ability to analyze what factors affect the current voltage behavior of OPV devices. By measuring the photocurrent versus voltage it can be determined if the low open circuit voltage is a result of a high diode current (dark current measurement) or the result of a drop off in photocurrent at higher voltages: i.e. is the open circuit voltage photocurrent or diode current limited. Furthermore, a liquid helium cryostat was integrated with the photocurrent set up to vary the temperature of the device. The photocurrent and dark currents as a function of voltage were measured at various low temperatures in order to provide insight into the factors that affect the open circuit voltage. Furthermore, the materials used in the devices were varied in order to determine the effect of molecular properties on the open circuit values as well as the influence of molecular design on the temperature at which maximum attainable open circuit voltage can be achieved. Preliminary results indicate that in some material systems which have a very low diode current, the open circuit voltage is limited by a drop off in photocurrent at a voltage near the open circuit condition. This behavior ultimately yields minimal change in open circuit voltage as the dark current is lowered with decreasing temperature giving nearly maximum obtainable voltage at room temperature. Yet in another material system, the photocurrent dropped off at voltages much beyond the open circuit condition but the dark current was high enough to limit the open circuit voltage. Thus, as the dark current is lowered with decreasing temperature the open circuit voltage was affected yielding maximum obtainable voltages at low temperatures. These results have currently yielded one publication yet uncovering more information on what effect the properties of the organic materials has on these trends is still currently underway in an ongoing collaboration between the two labs.
